     I have had a thorough review made of the facts raised by

Karachi 239 in which they reported that the Pakistan Air Force

claimed they had obtained the questionable starter (which was

the basic evidence in our case) from a ground power unit and

not from an airplane.

Obviously, all the circumstantial evidence,

including the way the starter first showed up in the inventory,

the' first reports to us, subsequent indications of embarrassment,

etc., would all indicate that our original conclusion was correct

that the starter did come from the Indonesian airplane.

Parther-

more, the stories told to U.S. military by Pak military about the

incident don't all agree.
For instance, the first volunteered .

story we had early in July indicated support was limited to some

maintenance work, "***and a fuel control valve."

Later, another

officer talking to the MAAG Chief apparently indicated that the

work done on the aircraft consisted of prop removal and repair

in which they said a MAP prop was first installed and then the

station commander ordered it removed and the original prop

repaired.'

They have been consistent in only one point, that

the Indonesian aircraft arrived in West Pakistan to do some

kind of a hauling job into the Gilgit area and that the whole

thing was arranged without the knowledge of the Air Force by

some other government agency.

I thought we had almost ironclad evidence in the starter

matter but find that our case falls apart because the starter

actually could have come, as the Paks now claim, from a ground

unit and not from an aircraft at all.

These ground units or

carts used to start jet aircraft include gas turbine compressors

similar to those used in the airborne units installed in the

C-130s and one such unit which the Paks could easily have, is

so similar to the airborne unit many of the parts are interchange-

able including the electrical starters.

Furthermore, because

these ground units are not as critical as the airborne units

they are not subject to as close control or modification and

as a result, while they would be improved as the opportunity

presented itself, the improvement would not be as mandatory as

in the airborne units, and old-style starters have been used

on them whenever they were available since the new ones were in

relatively short supply.

Thus, the story apparently volunteered

by the Paks,.reported in Karachi 239, 14 August, is an unden-

iably possible explanation.

MEMORANDUM FOR RECORD


SUBJECT: USS IBERTY

       About 0900 I was notified by Brigadier General Morrison

that the USS LIBERTY, an AGTR, had been hit by torpedo while on

station in the Mediterranean.

The critic provided coordinates

which showed that she was less than 14 miles off the coast of the

Sinai Peninsula, about mid-way between the Suez Canal and the

Gaza Strip.

The depth of water shown on the chart which I used

for plotting the position indicated about 30 fathoms.

A refined

position received in a subsequent report moved the ship two minutes

West, less than a mile closer to the Sinai Peninsula,and into water

which did not exceed 20 fathoms in depth.

After considerations of

personnel safety one of General Carter' s and my immediate concerns,

considering the depth of the water and the distance of the ship off

shore, had to do with the classified materials which she had on

board.

These materials consisted of a substantial amount of texta

data and some electronic equipment which would clearly reveal the

mission of the ship and U.S. capability to demultiplex the VHF

and UHF multichannel communications which she might intercept.

In a conversation with Captain Vineyard of the JRC I expressed my

concern that the written material be burned if at all possible and

that the electronic equipment be salvaged if that were possible.

Captain Vineyard had mentioned during this conversation that con-

sideration was then being given by some unnamed Washington authorI-

ties to sink the LIBERTY in order that newspaper men would be unable

to photograph her and thus inflame public opinion against the Israelis.
I made an impolite comment about that idea.

Subsequent reports indicated that the ship was listing badly

with 4 dead, some 50 injured, and that the ship had been able to

get underway and was proceeding northward at about 8 knots.

body.sentence: DEPARTMENT OF THE AIR FORCE
WASHINGTON 20330
OFFICE OF THE SECRETARY
September 9, 1968
MEMORANDUM FOR THE SECRETARY OF DEFENSE
SUBJECT: Draft Presidential Memorandum on Theater Nuclear Forces
I have reviewed the Draft Memorandum for the President on Theater Nuclear Forces and believe it proposes some fresh and productive approaches.
However, I have serious reservations about using the rationale contained in it to justify changes in our currently approved ...programs for theater nuclear forces.
In essence, the DPM analysis has not considered all feasible alternatives for the possible employment of theater nuclear forces nor explored rigorously those it has offered.

Nonetheless, it proposes reductions in forces and weapons which would weaken our deterrent posture at the theater nuclear level and limit the options available for responding to enemy actions at all levels below strategic nuclear war.
To adopt such a course of action based on the analysis to date seems to me imprudent.
It is well recognized policy that we intend to avoid the damage inherent in nuclear war -- at the theater level or at the strategic level --- except when our most vital interests are threatened.

Should we be forced to use nuclear weapons, however, we must have done beforehand everything we can to assure that we have in-being forces capable not only of containing an attack but of terminating the conflict on terms of relative advantage to the United States.

Since we must now plan on the basis that the enemy probably will respond with nuclear weapons to any nuclear attack by us --- and, in Europe at least, may himself initiate such attacks -- this task has become increasingly complex.
Nevertheless, we must continue to search for viable alternatives and refine our thinking in this area.

Within the general framework outlined above, I would like to comment on the following matters: first, the overall import of the DPM; second, the three employment proposals on which the DPM requested comment; third, the survivability of forces; fourth, the requirement for adequate theater nuclear forces; and finally, the requirement for chemical/biological (CB) weapons.
General McConnell's comments, which are attached, cover additional points as well as amplify these important issues.
The DPM would have U.S. theater forces rely increasingly on mass nuclear fire with fairly large yield weapons rather than on discrete fire with, where possible, small yield weapons.

Adoption of the DPM proposed policy would seem to be a reversion to discarded concepts and acceptance of a strategy that would leave the United States with no nuclear alternatives, to enormous destruction and mass civilian casualties within the theater.

This situation may be still the outcome even if either side initiates with small, accurate, and discriminate use of nuclear weapons; the confusion of nuclear battle and the risk of being preempted will create strong pressures to go to mass fire.
But mass destruction is surer and greater if mass fire with large weapons is adopted as the initial strategy.
This latter approach would lend support to the nuclear 'breakout' proponents and could lead to the eventual exclusion of nuclear weapons for U.S. theater forces.
There are, however, grave political disadvantages to this step.
It could also lead to the collapse of NATO.

If our allies believed that either we would not use nuclear weapons in their defense, or alternatively, if we did, it inevitably would be at the price of great destruction to their homelands and peoples while the enemy suffered no similar destruction, they understandably would not long remain allies.
Use of Nuclear Weapons on NATO Territory. I believe this idea has appeal for the initial employment of nuclear weapons.
It may be the best nuclear threshold we can find -- and it is certainly more flexible than no theater use at all of nuclear weapons.
I would caution, however, against a concept that under all conditions would limit the use of nuclear weapons to friendly territory.
I do not believe we can expect our allies to accept a strategy that contemplates decimation of their societies by friendly forces while leaving the aggressors' territory virtually intact.
Militarily also the approach has problems.
We have no reason to believe our opponents would follow any 'ground rules' on the use of weapons we established.
Yet unless we can either establish agreement to do so beforehand, or force observance during hostilities, we would be at a dangerous disadvantage.
Before firm conclusions can be reached on the overall merits of this proposal, more study is required.
First of all, we must carefully weigh the political and military arguments against the concept.
It is bound to encounter difficulties with our allies unless it is made clear that the concept refers to initial use only.
If it is linked to the tactic of terrain fire, it will face even more serious hurdles; those NATO countries that would become the nuclear battlefield would be hard put to follow the 'rules'.
To do so would be accepting self-inflicted destruction in the hope of arresting further Soviet advances.
Additionally, there is the question of Soviet response.
Our intelligence community estimates that any NATO use of nuclear weapons against Soviet forces, even though constrained, probably would result in a Soviet nuclear response.
Under the conditions postulated, they could launch this counterattack from a sanctuary, which would grant them a clear advantage.

Finally, is our command/control and assessment capability good enough to tell friendly from enemy nuclear weapons falling on our allies' territory if both sides were operating under the concept described in the DPM?
The preceding questions, and undoubtedly others, must be explored more fully before we can decide on the merits of the proposal.
Terrain Fire. This proposal, as described in the DPM, raises very serious questions.

Its greatest disadvantage from my point of view is its implications of intentionally increasing, rather than decreasing, the destructiveness of war -- a measure diametrically opposite to the purposes of our emphasis on non-nuclear capabilities.
There are other reasons also why terrain fire, as outlined in the DPM, should not be accepted as a basis for force requirements.
First, its operational feasibility has yet to be fully examined.
Next, its success is highly dependent on the enemy's playing the game our way and concentrating his forces.

Finally, if terrain fire is the initial NATO employment of nuclear weapons and is restricted to friendly territory, it is not clear how it would dissuade Soviet forces from responding with nuclear forces operating from sanctuaries so as to achieve a relatively favorable military balance with little damage to their own territory.
We may have to consider limited terrain fire in selected circumstances, such as against a massed attack.
If discrete fire fails to halt the enemy advance.
But we should rely on it if at all as one of the later, not earlier alternatives, and preferably on enemy rather than friendly territory.
It may not be possible to contain a non-nuclear attack against NATO using the conventional weapons and forces proposed in this series of DPMs.
However, ADMs and discrete nuclear fire should be effective in inhibiting massed attacks.
With this restriction on enemy movement, nuclear air attacks against logistic concentrations, troop movements, and other suitable targets would prove very lucrative.
Nothing in the DPM demonstrates that such discrete use of nuclear weapons is an invalid concept.
Use of ADMs

With respect to the employment of Atomic Demolition Munitions (ADMs), I agree that we should avoid their use until we have tested our conventional defenses and determined the extent of an enemy attack.
However, if we are going to delay employment of ADMs to rear defense positions, we could require more rather than fewer to stop the momentum of the attack.
The DPM would reduce the ADM stockpile by over 50% to a level stated to be sufficient to meet our needs for all theaters and to provide a 20% reserve.
The supporting analysis and rationale for this proposed reduction, however, are not provided.
Until a comprehensive study of our ADM requirements supports a reduction of this magnitude, I recommend that we maintain our present stockpile of ADMs.
In summary, I agree we should continue to study the three employment concepts outlined in the DPM, particularly the initial use of nuclear weapons over NATO territory.

In their present form, the concepts are undeveloped and fragmentary; until our analyses are further along and we have a firm basis to accept or reject the proposals, we should not base weapons requirements on them.

Survivability of Forces. The DPM asserts that tactical aircraft are vulnerable and therefore add little to our nuclear deterrent while land based missiles, such as the Pershing, are relatively invulnerable.

SUBJECT: Vietnamization Meeting with Secretary Laird

    Dr. Nutter, Dr. Doolin, Gen. Karhohs, Gen. Pursley and I met with Mr.

Laird at 0930 on April 23 to discuss Vietnam and related matters.

Mr. Laird led off by asking Dr. Doolin how the hearings went on Thursday

before the Kennedy Subcommittee on Refugees.

Dr. Doolin said he thought

things went reasonably well, but the press coverage certainly didn't give

the Administration side much coverage.

He said he talked to Kennedy after

the meeting and tried to explain the Defense position in more detail.

Kennedy had made a big point of the

Cambodia refugee situation.

Dennis said he tried to point out that this is

something that is not under our control at all as the Cambodians are handling

it themselves.

We might not be entirely,happy the way they are handling things

but it was not to the American interest to get involved in this situation

unless absolutely essential.

Gen. Karhohs said that the NSC staff had asked for a Troop Contributing

Country (TCC) paper for consideration at the Senior Review Group on Tuesday.

He said they were working on it and expected to have the paper available

He didn't feel

they could really prepare the paper until after the TCC meeting on Friday.

Gen. Karhohs said the JCS had submitted their paper on the RVNAF Improve-

yes, that was right.

THE SECRETARY OF DEFENSE

 WASHINGTON D.C. 20301

6 January 1972

MEMORANDUM FOR THE PRESIDENT

SUBJECT: Appointment of a Deputy Secretary of Defense

As we have discussed on previous occasions, it is most important

 that a Deputy Secretary of Defense be appointed as soon as possible.

In the period just ahead it will be virtually impossible for me to

 continue to manage the internal affairs of the Department effectively

 without a Deputy Secretary on board because of the tremendous demands

 Congress will be making on my time in testifying on your Defense

 Budget.

There are some twelve committees and subcommittees to whom

 I must be personally responsive in the early months of each year.

Beginning in February, some 45 days of almost constant testimony

 will be required of me personally.

As to candidates for the position of Deputy Secretary of Defense,

 I began an extensive talent search some nine months ago.

I personally

 have interviewed some thirty people and reviewed the qualifications

 of some 60 others.

This talent search has gone forward with the able

 assistance of your personnel staff; in particular, through a close

 working relationship between Fred Malek of your staff and Carl Wallace

 of my staff.

Invariably in my interviews with potential candidates from outside

 Government, the ultimate problem seems to come down to this

 comment: "In a year, perhaps, I would have no problems and could

 be in a position to divest myself of all business interests but I

 could not be in a position to join the Department in the immediate

 future."

The exceptions to this rule invariably turn out to be second-raters

 whom it would take at least nine or ten months to educate

 properly.

Especially in this year 1972, we cannot afford an on-the-job

 training program in a Department that will occupy so much of

 the attention of our critics and opponents.

In addition, it seems

 everyone I talk to from the outside would love to work at the State

 Department or be an Ambassador to some country, but when it comes

 down to this building, the tendency is to run like scared rabbits.

I would also point out that we will be creating a 2nd Deputy

 Secretary of Defense -- hopefully, soon after Congress convenes.

THE SECRETARY OF DEFENSE

     WAbHINl,ON  C 20301



Dear Bob:



     I know we agree on the course we should pursue in Southeast

Asia.

We want to protect US interests, and to achieve US objec-

tives, in Southeast Asia.

We also want to end the war -- not

just for the US forces, but for all the people in Southeast Asia.
We are on course, in my judgment.

As the President notes

in his 1972 Foreign Policy Report, "We are ending American in-

volvement in the war while making it possible for,those who do

not wish to be dominated by outside forces to carry on their own

defense."

As you know, we are simultaneously pressing for political

steps which will turn down the level of hostilities among the

Southeast Asian nations, alleviate their suffering, and even pro-

vide the opportunity for renewed -- and peaceful -- growth.

The credit for much of the progress we have made must go in

no small measure to.

you and to the Air Force for which you provide

such excellent leadership.

Your contributions have taken, and

continue to take, many forms.

Notable among them have been your

help in force management, in resource allocation, in accelerated

Vietnamization, in contributions to public understanding of our

role, and in consistently wise counsel to me.
I truly appreciate the contributions you have made.

I know

they will continue.

In the process, we must, I believe, keep

our perspective on the overall US interests and objectives.

It

is the trend that is important.

There will be occasional deviations

from the trend -- or, to use an Air Force figure of speech, an

occasional "dog-leg" in our course.- Perhaps I should be more

explicit at times in explaining those "dog-legs," especially to

those -- like you -- on whom -J rely so heavily.

Let me assure

you now the course has not changed, recent changes in air activity

notwithstanding.

Staying on course and reaching our objective will be a function,

in no small measure, of your continued assistance and support.

I

again want to express appreciation for that which has carried us

this far; and I solicit strongly the added measure which will help

carry us the rest of the way.

Sincerely,
